Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about J.K. Rowling's creation story for Harry Potter, including the famous train inspiration and her cafe writing process:

## The Train Inspiration (1990)

The initial idea for Harry Potter came to J.K. Rowling in 1990 during a delayed train journey from Manchester to London. She didn't have a pen with her and was too shy to ask for one, but this turned out to be fortunate as it gave her the full four hours on the train to develop ideas for the book. 

Rowling has described this moment: "Harry Potter came to me on the train in 1990. I was sitting there just staring out of the window and the idea just fell out of nowhere – it was the purest stroke of inspiration I've ever had in my life". The idea of a boy going to a wizarding school struck her, and as she watched the trees rush past her window, the Hogwarts castle loomed large in her imagination.

By the end of that train journey, she knew it was going to be a seven-book series, which she admits was "extraordinarily arrogant for somebody who had never been published".

## The Writing Process and Cafe Years

After the initial inspiration, it took Rowling five years to write the first book in the series. During this period, her life underwent significant changes: her mother died, she moved to Portugal, got married, had her daughter Jessica, divorced, and moved to Edinburgh with Jessica and the first three chapters of Harry Potter in a suitcase.

In Edinburgh, she trained and taught as a French teacher but continued to write in every spare moment she had, mostly in cafés around the city, whilst Jessica slept in her pram. Many days she would wheel little Jessica in her pram to a cafe, order a cup of coffee, get her daughter to sleep, and then keep writing until the little one woke up.

## Methodical Planning Beyond Inspiration

Contrary to the popular "sudden inspiration" narrative, Rowling was highly methodical - she spent the next five years engaged in creative iterations, developing the plots of all seven books, and writing the first book. She created fifteen variations of the first chapter alone, as well as a chart that included every single character in Harry Potter's class at Hogwarts.

Rowling describes using tables with color coded sections, outlines, character pieces, red herrings, and clues all mixed in, and everything starts with pen and paper - she writes everything out by hand before typing it up.

The story demonstrates that while the initial spark came from inspiration on that train journey, the actual creation of Harry Potter was the result of years of dedicated, methodical work and countless hours spent writing in Edinburgh cafes while caring for her young daughter.
